message.content: This question requires basic understanding of dominant and recessive traits. A dominant trait will always be visible when both the dominant and recessive alleles are present. Option (A) is incorrect because if either the dominant or recessive allele is missing, the dominant trait will still be visible. Option (B) is incorrect because if both the dominant and recessive alleles are missing, there will be no trait visible. Option (D) is incorrect because if the recessive allele is present, it will not be visible, and the dominant trait will still be visible. Only option (C) states the correct condition for the dominant trait to be visible.

This question relates to basic knowledge of genetics and inheritance patterns. In genetics, there are dominant and recessive traits. Dominant traits are always visible when present, regardless of whether the recessive trait is present or not. Option (A) is incorrect because the presence or absence of one trait does not affect the visibility of the dominant trait. Option (B) is incorrect because if both traits are missing, there is nothing to be visible. Option (D) is incorrect because recessive traits are not visible when the dominant trait is present. Only option (C) states that both traits are present, which allows the dominant trait to be visible.

This question requires basic knowledge about genetics and dominant and recessive traits. In genetics, a dominant trait is one that masks or overrides the presence of a recessive trait. When both the dominant and recessive traits are present, the dominant trait will always be visible or expressed. This is because the dominant alleles have a stronger influence on the phenotype (observable trait) than the recessive alleles. Option (A) is incorrect because if either the dominant or recessive trait is missing, the dominant trait will still be visible. Option (B) is incorrect because if both the dominant and recessive traits are missing, there would be no trait to observe. Option (D) is incorrect because the presence of the recessive trait does not indicate whether the dominant trait will be visible or not.

This question requires knowledge about dominant and recessive traits in genetics. A dominant trait will always be visible when both the dominant and recessive traits are present. In option (A), if either the dominant or recessive trait is missing, the dominant trait may still be visible. In option (B), if both the dominant and recessive traits are missing, there is no dominant trait to be visible. In option (D), if the recessive trait is present, it does not necessarily mean that the dominant trait will not be visible. Only option (C) states that the dominant trait will always be visible when both the dominant and recessive traits are present.

This question pertains to basic knowledge about dominant and recessive traits. In genetics, dominant traits are always visible when the individual has at least one copy of the dominant allele. So when both the dominant and recessive alleles are present (both are present), the dominant trait will be visible. Option (A) is incorrect because if either the dominant or recessive allele is missing, the dominant trait can still be visible if the individual has the other allele. Option (B) is incorrect because if both the dominant and recessive alleles are missing, there would be no alleles to determine the trait. Option (D) is incorrect because the question is asking about when the dominant trait is visible, not when the recessive trait is present.

This question is about the inheritance of traits and requires knowledge of dominant and recessive alleles. The dominant trait will always be visible when both the dominant and recessive alleles are present. Option (A) is incorrect because if either the dominant or recessive allele is missing, the dominant trait can still be visible. Option (B) is incorrect because if both alleles are missing, there would be no trait visible. Option (D) is incorrect because the presence of the recessive allele does not guarantee that the dominant trait will be visible. Only when both the dominant and recessive alleles are present (and the dominant allele is dominant over the recessive one) will the dominant trait be visible.

This question relates to the concept of dominant and recessive traits in genetics. A dominant trait will always be visible (expressed) when both the dominant and recessive alleles are present. In option (C), when both alleles are present, the dominant trait will be expressed. Option (A) is incorrect because if either allele is missing, the dominant trait can still be visible. Option (B) is incorrect because if both alleles are missing, no trait will be expressed. Option (D) is also incorrect because the presence of recessive alleles does not guarantee the visibility of the dominant trait.

This question is related to the inheritance and expression of dominant and recessive traits. When both the dominant and recessive allele for a trait are present, the dominant trait will always be visible. This is because the dominant allele will override the recessive allele and determine the physical characteristics. Option (A) is incorrect because if either the dominant or recessive allele is missing, the trait may or may not be visible depending on the presence of the other allele. Option (B) is incorrect because if both alleles for the trait are missing, then the trait will not be visible at all. Option (D) is incorrect because the recessive trait will only be visible if both alleles for the trait are recessive and the dominant allele is absent.

This question is testing understanding of dominant and recessive traits in genetics. When both the dominant and recessive traits are present, the dominant trait will always be visible because it masks the expression of the recessive trait. Option (A) is incorrect because if either trait is missing, it means that only one trait is present and it may be either dominant or recessive. Option (B) is also incorrect because if both traits are missing, there is nothing present to be visible. Option (D) is incorrect because the presence of recessive traits does not necessarily mean that the dominant trait will be visible.

This question involves understanding the principles of dominant and recessive traits in genetics. A dominant trait is always visible in an individual as long as at least one copy of the dominant allele is present. Therefore, when both dominant alleles are present, the dominant trait will always be visible. Option (A) is incorrect because if either of the dominant alleles is missing, the dominant trait can still be visible. Option (B) is incorrect because if both alleles are missing, there would be no trait present at all. Option (D) is incorrect because recessive traits are not always visible, especially if a dominant allele is present.

This question relates to the concept of dominant and recessive traits in genetics. If a trait is dominant, it means that it will be expressed and visible even if only one copy of the gene for that trait is present. In this question, it states that both traits are present, meaning that at least one copy of the dominant trait is present. Therefore, the dominant trait will always be visible. Option (A) is incorrect because the dominant trait will still be visible even if the recessive trait is missing. Option (B) is incorrect because if both traits are missing, then there would be no traits visible. Option (D) is also incorrect because it states that the recessive trait is present, but in this question, it specifically mentions that both traits are present.

This question requires basic knowledge about genetics and dominant and recessive traits. The dominant trait will always be visible when both the dominant and recessive alleles are present. This is because the dominant allele will override the recessive allele and determine the phenotype or physical appearance of the organism. Option (A) is incorrect because if either allele is missing, it means there is only one allele present and the dominant trait may not be visible. Option (B) is incorrect because if both alleles are missing, there are no alleles present to determine the phenotype. Option (D) is incorrect because the presence of the recessive allele does not guarantee that the dominant trait will be visible.

This question requires knowledge about dominant and recessive traits. In genetics, dominant traits are expressed when at least one copy of the dominant gene is present. Therefore, the dominant trait will always be visible when both copies of the gene, whether dominant or recessive, are present. Option (A) is incorrect because if either the dominant or recessive gene is missing, the recessive trait may be visible. Option (B) is also incorrect because if both copies of the gene are missing, no trait will be visible. Option (D) is incorrect because the presence of the recessive gene does not necessarily mean that the dominant trait will not be visible.

This question requires basic knowledge about dominant and recessive traits in genetics. In genetics, dominant traits are those that are expressed or visible when an individual inherits one copy of the dominant allele. Option (A) is incorrect because if either the dominant or recessive allele is missing, the dominant trait will still be visible if the dominant allele is present. Option (B) is incorrect because if both alleles are missing, no trait will be visible. Option (D) is incorrect because the presence of the recessive allele does not determine whether the dominant trait will be visible. Only when both copies of the gene carry the dominant allele (both are present) will the dominant trait be visible.

This question requires knowledge about dominant and recessive traits. A dominant trait is always expressed and visible when it is present, regardless of whether the recessive trait is also present. Option (A) is incorrect because if either the dominant or recessive trait is missing, then that trait will not be visible. Option (B) is incorrect because if both the dominant and recessive traits are missing, then there is no trait to be visible. Option (D) is incorrect because the presence of the recessive trait does not guarantee that the dominant trait will be visible. Only option (C) correctly states that the dominant trait will always be visible when both the dominant and recessive traits are present.

This question is related to basic knowledge of genetics and dominant and recessive traits. The dominant trait will always be visible when both dominant and recessive traits are present, as the dominant gene will mask the recessive gene. Options (A) and (B) are incorrect because they suggest that the dominant trait may not be visible if certain genes are missing. Option (D) is also incorrect as it suggests that the recessive trait is always visible, which is not the case.

This question is related to basic genetics and the laws of inheritance. The dominant trait, by definition, is expressed whenever it is present, regardless of whether or not the recessive trait is present. Therefore, option (C) is correct as both traits need to be present for the dominant trait to be visible. Options (A) and (B) are incorrect because the presence or absence of one trait does not determine the visibility of the dominant trait. Option (D) is also incorrect because the expression of the recessive trait does not affect the visibility of the dominant trait.

This question is about genetics and dominant and recessive traits. The correct answer is option (C), which states that the dominant trait will always be visible when both alleles (versions of a gene) are present. This is because the dominant allele masks the recessive allele, and its characteristic is expressed. Options (A) and (B) are incorrect because they indicate a situation where one or both alleles are missing, which has nothing to do with expressing dominant traits. Option (D) is incorrect because if the recessive allele is present alone, it is expressed, not the dominant trait.

This question requires basic knowledge about genetics and dominant and recessive traits. When a dominant trait is present in an organism, it will always be visible or expressed in the phenotype, even if the recessive trait is also present. Therefore, option (C) is the correct answer. Options (A) and (B) are incorrect because the absence of either trait does not affect the expression of the other. Option (D) is also incorrect because recessive traits are not expressed in the phenotype when a dominant trait is present.

This question is related to the concept of dominant and recessive traits in genetics. When a dominant trait is present, it will always be visible, regardless of whether the recessive trait is present or missing. Option (A) and (B) are incorrect because they refer to when one or both traits are missing, which is not relevant to the visibility of dominant traits.
